column3: Community
I see positive conversation (ex. Friendly chitchat, education, humor) on the platform.
column4: This question aims to understand the frequency of positive environments on social media. In general, people do frequently see positive conversation on social media, more frequently than negative conversation.
column5: People frequently see positive conversation on Facebook. This is because communities are built around family, friends, and people in groups with mutual interests.
column6: On average people frequently see positive conversation on LinkedIn. Although most users occasionally see this, many see positive conversation very frequently. As a professional setting, LinkedIn will be polite and may congratulate others on achievements.
column7: Twitter users see friendly conversation frequently to occasionally. Q
column8: Frequently see positivity. Q, especially from friends and family.
column9: Q. More frequently than other social media, Reddit may be more community based
column10: Very friendly, more community based
column11: Frequently, community based. Q
column12: Varying responses but leaning very frequently, app for friends to support each other
column13: Occasionally, no specfic lean. Depends on comments, can vary significantly.
column14: Frequently, may be friends supporting friends similar to BeReal
column15: Occasionally, leaning rarely. May be more negative conversation
column16: Frequently, Q depends on who you follow, chats tend to be positive
column17: Responses vary, but following positive accounts will lead to positive conversation.

column3: I see negative conversation (ex. disputes, name-calling, trolling) on the platform.
column4: This question aims to understand the frequency of negative environments on social media. In general, people do often see negative conversation on social media, less frequently than positive conversation.
column5: Frequently see negative conversation on Facebook. Extended families may argue, or Q
column6: People very rarely see negativity on LinkedIn. Since this is a professional environment, politeness is encouraged.
column7: Very frquently, most see it occasionally if not more often. Q
column8: Occasionally. Q, but friends and family may have less negativity
column9: Frequently. Q
column10: Occasionally, Q but more niche community discourages negativity
column11: Frequently, Q. Short content may lose nuance.
column12: Most say never. Close friends in personal community
column13: Occasionally, Q. Depends on comments
column14: Rarely. Personal relationships are less negative, but Snap is less personal than BeReal
column15: Very frequently, unanimous response. Hostile environment
column16: Occasionally leaning rarely. Random chatters can be negative, depends who you watch, Q
column17: Some communities or users may debate or troll to upset others. Less personal relationships cause more negativity

column3: I see perspectives and opinions that are different from my own on the platform.
column4: Seeing different opinions is both good and bad, as it prevents echo chambers but may cause discomfort. In general people occasionally see opinions that differ from theirs.
column5: Q
column6: Q
column7: R
column8: Q
column9: R, wide community
column10: Occasionally Q, but many responses say rarely, may be echo chamber to some communities
column11: Occasionally Q, but many responses say rarely, may be echo chamber to some communities
column12: Responeses mostly occasionally or never; may be an echo chamber but may also be that friends are not posting their opinions
column13: Q, YouTube content may mention other views to counter them
column14: Rarely, may be echo chamber or friends not posting opinions often
column15: Very frequently, nearly unanimous response. Wide variety of opinions related to negativity
column16: Most people say rarely, may be echo chamber or lack of voiced opinions
column17: People occasionally see views that differ from theirs, which may lead to debate
column18: Frequently, this may be linked with negative conversation

column3: The platform prioritizes my friendsâ€™ posts over other posts.
column4: Overall, social media was built on friendly connections, but, in recent years, sponsored and recommended content is making waves.
column5: Facebook remains a popular platform for connecting with loved ones, however, the platform frequently displays newsfeed and recommended content. Although users still primarily see posts from their friends, there is a tight balance between these posts and the suggested content, while other social media platforms, like BeReal and Instagram, place a greater emphasis on personal connections.
column6: Although LinkedIn is definitely a platform to connect with coworkers, your feed may have a mix of corporate and personal posts. Respondents tend to agree that the feed tends to proiritize connections, but not as strongly as places like Instagram or BeReal. Once again, we are unsure if our respondents tend to use the feed or just the profile features, so these answers may be skewed.
column7: Highly varied, You will definitely still see the postsof people you follow, but the users tend to "slightly agree," while places like BeReal and Instagram are stronger in this regard.
column8: Instagram still tends to be a place to follow friends and post photos, even if recommended content is being pushed more into the feed. Instagram users tend to agree that they will see their friends first.
column9: This social media tends not to show you content from people you know or follow, instead using it's community structure to show you posts from your requested circles.
column10: High variance in the agree, but tend to agree. Mutual culture
column11: This social media tends not to show you content from people you know or follow, instead relying on it recommendation algorithm to keep you coming back.
column12: Only friends, unique
column13: This social media tends not to show you content from people you know or follow, instead relying on it recommendation algorithm to keep you coming back.
column14: Lost influencers, mostly just friends on stories.
column15: The anonymity on 4chan means that you will absolutely not know who are your friends on 4chan. 100% of respondents agree that this isn't the space to see people you know in real life.
column16: This social media tends not to show you content from people you know or follow, instead relying on you favorite streamers to keep you coming back.

column3: The platform prioritizes sponsored posts over other posts.
column4: This question aims to understand whether user communities and their posts are prioritized over advertisements and sponsorships.
column5: Users strongly agree that Facebook prioritizes sponsored posts, meaning that corporate interest may be prioritized over user posts. Instagram follows in agreement, and Meta Inc. is well known for profiting off of advertisements.
column6: Q
column7: Q
column8: Users strongly agree that Instagram prioritizes sponsored posts, meaning that corporate interest may be prioritized over user posts. Facebook follows in agreement, and Meta Inc. is well known for profiting off of advertisements.
column9: People slightly disgree that Reddit prioritizes sponsored posts. These communities feel more natural, and less corporate
column10: Users either slightly agree or strongly disagree that Tumblr prioritizes sponsored posts; it is possible that people use Tumblr on the web, and have ad blockers, but Tumblr does push some sponsored posts.
column11: Q
column12: Strong disagree, BeReal has no ads or sponsorships
column14: People agree and often strongly agree that YouTube prioritizes sponsored posts. This includes unskippable ads. Similar to Meta Inc., YouTube is owned by Google, which is a high-profit company
column15: People strongly disagree, 4Chan has sponsored ads at the top of forums, but not within posts
column16: Responses vary, but Q
column17: Peple tend to slightly agree that this prioritizes sponsored posts over other posts. While sponsorship is common, other posts are still very much visible.

column3: I see two-way discussion between content creators and audiences on the platform.
column4: In general, people say they occasionally see two-way discussion on social media.
column5: Most people agree that two-way discussion is common on Facebook, and people overwhelmingly see discussion frequently. This may be because people often respond to posts from friends and family on their feed.
column6: Most people occasionally see two-way discussion on LinkedIn, with most responses between being frequent and rare. This may be because LinkedIn is a professional environment with users discussing topics such as new jobs, research and new ideas.
column7: Most people frequently see two-way discussion. This may be due to Twitter's reply feature allowing for easy, brief responses to posts.
column8: People overwhelmingly say tht they occasionally see two-way discussion on Instagram. Instagram is not built for long-form conversation, but users may spend time having discussions in the coments of posts.
column9: Most people see two-way discussion on Reddit, with responses leaning towards frequently or very frequently. Due to Reddit's nature as a forum-based social media, many posts are written with the intention of starting a conversation for users to reply to.
column10: High variance, but people tend to see two-way discussion very frequently. Tumblr makes it very easy to see responses to posts.
column11: There is high variance, with most people occasionally seeing two-way discussion on TikTok. While duets, live streams and comments are means to have two-way discussions, they are not frequent.
column12: Responses are either "frequently" or "never." Since this is friends-only, this is contingent on whether or not your friends will respond to each other's posts.
column13: Occasionally or rarely, creators may respond to comments but discussion is not a priority
column14: Most conversation is private, most respondents say they rarely see it with many people seeing conversation very rare/never
column15: Too low confidence to say
column16: Very frequently, streamers tend to respond to chatters

column3: It is easy to make new friends on the platform.
column4: This question was aimed whether users are able to exand their community by making new personal connections. In general, social media users tend to slightly disagree, thus making new friends on social media tends to be somewhat difficult.
column5: In general, people agree that it is easy to make new friends on Facebook. There are a considerable number of people that disagree, and this may deend on your involvement in groups or other pages.
column6: In general, people lean towards slightly agreeing that it is easy to make new friends on LinkedIn. This may be because LinkedIn recommends people within the same organizations, so they may suggest poeple you know or have similar interest to.
column7: While people lean towards slightly agree, the responses vary significantly. Users may find it easy or difficult to make friends.
column8: People slightly disagree that making new friends is easy on Instagram. This may be because users tend to follow pre-existing friends.
column9: People overwhelmingly disagree that it is easy to make new friends on Reddit. This may be because Reddit is topic driven and does not emphasize following other users, and conversations are often tied to a specific topic or subject.
column10: Although there are few responses, people tend to agree that making new friends on Tumblr is easy. This may be due to Tumblr's culture of "mutual" followers, and the ability to chat via replying to posts or reblogging.
column11: In general, people disagree that you can make new friends on TikTok. Since TikTok is only videos and you often cannot message people that are not following you, communication is de-emphasized.
column12: There are very few responses to this question, with most people either slightly agreeing or disagreeing. This may be ebcause BeReal prioritizes your existing friends, and does not aim for you to make new friends through the platform.
column13: People strongly disagree, since YouTube has no way to message other users or add friends, and recommends content for entertainment.
column14: Responses vary here. In general, people slightly disagree, but many people do also agree. This may be subjective since Snapchat relies primarily on pre-existing friendships, through which some people are able to make new friends.
column15: Users strongly disagree here. 4Chan allows no usernames or direct messaging, so staying in contact with an anonymous user will be difficult.
column16: Responses vary, but people slightly disagree. This is because Twitch's design focuses more on individual streams rather than direct interaction between users, however people may still make friends from these streamer's communities.

column3: Self
The users I interact with feel like individual human beings.
column4: This question was aimed to touch on the feeling that the internet "isn't real" and that other users may be bots or not. In general, people do agree that they are interacting with other individuals.
column5: People agree that they interact with other individuals on Facebook. Often these are people that users know, or friends of their friends, so this close connection helps users feel more real.
column6: People agree that users feel like real individuals, but slightly less than Facebook. This may be due to LinkedIn's professional nature and the frequency of recruiters who use automated messages to reach potential candidates.
column7: Q, this may be due to bots, or because 280-character text posts lose some nuance of real people.
column8: Q. On Instagram, posts may be filtered to show a person's ideal image, which may feel less real.
column9: Q. There is a considerable amount of disagreeing, which may be from trolls, but people tend to agree.
column10: People tend to agree. This may be due to Tumblr's niche content
column11: Q, 60 second videos may also lose nuance similar to Twitter
column12: Overwhelmingly agree. This is the idea behind BeReal, that you see your friends being authentic
column13: Varied answers, but people slightly agree. Users don't tend to interact with creators, but commentors may feel like bots.
column14: People agree. They are mostly interacting with their friends. But similar to Instagram, Snapchat has filters and may feel less authentic
column15: Answers very significantly. Low confidence. Many people strongly disagree, which may be due to a high presence of trolls
column16: People tend to agree, very few disagrees. Streams are slow-paced and people likely gravitate towards streams that feel personable and authentic. The concept of streams being live also makes people feel more real.
column17: People slightly agree that they are interacting with individuals, although a considerable amount disagrees.

column3: The platform encourages me to present an identity.
column4: This question aims at how identity-focused a social media is. In general, people agree that social media encourages identity.
column5: Q
column6: Q, specifically requires a professional identity
column7: Q, slight agree
column8: Q
column9: Disagree, not encouraged to present an identity. De-emphasized identity, little profile customization, and focus on topics over people
column10: Varied answer with little confidence, most responses slightly agree
column11: Strong range of responses, people slightly agree. People are encouraged to post themselves, but identity is not priority
column12: Q, all about authentic identity
column13: Users disagree, identity is not emphasized compared to viewing, and users are not incentivized to post.
column14: Q
column15: High variance and low confidence, responses agree and disagree. Not much to say
column16: Varied responses, largely disagree. More about watching than presenting an identity
column17: People tend to agree. This social media is more personal, revolving around the traditional profile and feed of friend/following posts

column3: The persona I present on the platform is authentic.
column4: This question aims to identify whether people believe they are being themselves on social media. Most people agree, with many strongly agreeing that they are authentic.
column5: People agree that their Facebook personas are authentic. This is how they present themselves to family and friends, so it will relate to themselves.
column6: People strongly agree that their LinkedIn personas are authentic. This is how they present themselves to coworkers and peers, so it will relate to themselves.
column7: In general, people agree that their Twitter accounts represent an authentic persona. However a large number of people disagree, and believe their personas are not authentic.
column8: People agree that their Instagram personas are authentic. Like Facebook, this is how they present themselves to family and friends, so it will relate to themselves.
column9: People agree that their Reddit personas are authentic. Their posts and topics relate to their interests.
column10: Answers vary. Not everyone on Tumblr will be presenting an authentic persona, but many will be.
column11: Most people agree that their personas are authentic. However, a significant amount of people disagree.
column12: People agree that their BeReal personas are authentic. This is how they present themselves to family and friends by showing a daily image, so it will relate to themselves.
column13: Despire that identity is not emphasized, most people still agree that their personas are authentic. Likely, when commenting on videos they are not trolling
column14: Most responses agree, people are being authentic with their friends
column15: Varying answers, most people slightly disagree. May be trolling or disingenuous
column16: People agree or slightly agree, low variance. People are being themselves, but the platform does not significantly encourage self.

column3: The platform enables me to customize my profile.
column4: In general, people agree that social media allows profile customization. However the more customization, the more the social media promotes self identity.
column5: Users agree strongly that Facebook enables profile customization. This includes headers and profile pictures, however all posts also appear on the user's profile.
column6: Users strongly that LinkedIn enables profile customization. This is one of LinkedIn's key features, as your profile showcases your professional identity and contains your skills and experiences.
column7: People agree that Twitter allows profile customization to an extent. However this is limited to profile picture, header and description.
column8: People agree that Instagram allows profile customization to an extent. However this is primarily limited to profile picture, header and description. Instagram does also allow users to feature stories on their profile as well.
column9: People slightly agree that Reddit enables customization. This includes a profile picture, banner, display name and about section, but since following is de-emphasized, these features are entirely based on preference.
column10: Most people strongly agree. Not only does Tumblr have the traditional display name, about, profile picture and header, it also allows users to adjust the color scheme of their blogs or completely edit the HTML of their web blogs.
column11: People tend to slightly agree. TikTok allows profile pictures, names and descriptions
column12: There is high variance, but most people slightly agree. BeReal allows a profile picture and name.
column13: People tend to slightly agree. Channels can have a profile picture, header and description, but these are not required or emphasized.
column14: People agree, Snapchat allows for the creation of Bitmoji, a customizable avatar.
column15: People strongly disagree, you cannot create or customize a profile on 4Chan
column16: People slightly agree, Twitch allows for a profile picture, name, header and about. However only name is visible on comments

column3: I spend time viewing and curating my own profile.
column4: This question aims to emphasize how much time is spent on profile customization. There is high variance, but in general uses do not curate or view profiles.
column5: Q
column6: Users agree that they curate their profiles. This is the main feature of LinkedIn and profiles are emphasized to other users, so curating a profile is important.
column7: Q
column8: Q. Some people agree, and do spend time customizing their profile, but most do not. May look back at photos and memories more than other social media
column9: Q, low options or emphasis on profiles
column10: High variance, equal amounts agree and disagree. Option to curate, not needed
column11: Strong disagree Q, profiles not emphasized. Mostly for watching
column12: High variance low confidence, people may look back at their memories
column13: Strong disagree, profiles not viewed or modified. Mostly for watching
column14: Q lean disagree, people may customize their bitmojis but SC does not have much profile to view or curate
column15: People strongly disagree, you cannot view a profile on 4Chan
column16: Most people strongly disagree, profiles are not viewed after creation, no emphasis. Streamers may curate
column17: People slightly disagree that they spend time curating their profiles, which means they likely do not edit it after creation.

column3: Discovery
I see posts by small creators.
column4: Q
column5: Q, most people see small creators
column6: Q, people follow peers and professionals but may see posts from large organizations
column7: Q
column8: Q
column9: People see posts by small creeators more frequently on Reddit than average. This may be due to Reddit being a topic-based platform, and creator following is de-emphasized
column10: Tumbr users say that they very frequently see posts by small creators. On tumblr, follow counts are not visible, so most creators on the platform feel small.
column11: Q, more frequent than occasional. Algorithm can push anyone's videos
column12: VF and Never; all friends so most users are small creators, and many respondants may not consider their friends creators
column13: P; occasionally or rarely. Many people may only be recommended large accounts related to accounts they already follow.
column14: High variance, but most people answer never. They do not consider their friends creators, and SC hosts creators but these are not emphasized
column15: High variance, Q, LC, lean towards VF since most people are anonymous, some users may not consider other posters "creators"
column16: Occasionally with wide variance: Most people may watch their favorite streamers who are large creators, others may have favorite streamers who are small, or watch friends
column17: Most people say that they see posts by small creators on social media occasionally, with many seeing this content frequently.

column3: On average, how long do you spend in a single session on the platform?
column4: People overwhelmingly spend less than 10 minutes on social media, with higher time periods following almost an exponential decay
column5: Most people use Facebook for less than 30 minutes, and many use it for less than 10. People may be making a quick update, responding to messages, or viewing a few posts.
column6: Most people spend less than 10 minutes on LinkedIn. Users may be checkinf for updates, sending quick messages, or briefly updating their profiles.
column7: Most people spend less than ten minutes on Twitter. While others spend 30 minutes or less, almost nobody spends more than 30 minutes. This may be due to Twitter's content being limited to 280 characters.
column8: Most people spend less than ten minutes on Instagram, but there is high variance. While viewing a few posts would require spending less than ten seconds, Instagram features messaging and video reels which may cause users to spend more time on the app.
column9: While most people spend less than ten minutes on Reddit, the amount of time spent varies. Reddit posts may be longer-form, and reading and responding to detailed posts may take considerable time.
column10: There is high variance, but most tumblr users spend 30 minutes or less on the platform. Posts may be longer-form content, or users may enjoy posts more often.
column11: TikTok has the highest amount of responses using the app in sessions of less than ten minutes or more than one hour. Despite TikToks being one minute or less, meaning that users can view one or two TikToks then close the apQ, however the algorithm is also good at recommending more content to watch.
column12: Unanimously, all users spend less than ten minutes per session. This is because BeReal has very little content, aside from posting within a 2 minute window and viewing friends' posts.
column13: Watch time varies, but most people spend well beyond 10 minutes on YouTube. This is because most videos that are not YouTube Shorts are above ten minutes, with many streams and videos spanning over an hour
column14: Nearly everyone uses Snapchat for ten minutes or less. This is because Snapchat is designed for short, quick interactions and disappearing messages emphasize temporary use.
column15: Most people spend less than 10 minutes on 4Chan. These posts also tend to be short
column16: Most people spend over 30 minutes on Twitch, with many spending more than an hour. This is because Twitch focused on long form content in the form of video streams, which often run for many hours

column3: This platform prioritizes ______ content.
column4: In general, social media prioritizes video more than text or image content.
column5: Many people feel that Facebook prioritizes image content, although answers vary, meaning that Facebook may support a variety of content
column6: Most people believe LinkedIn prioritizes text content. This includes status updates, research and job postings.
column7: Most people agree that Twitter prioritizes text content. This supports Twitter's design, which supports 280 character text posts. Images without text may be posted, but less frequently.
column8: Most people agree that Instagram prioritizes image content, which was the original goal of Instagram. However, more than 1/5 of responses agreed that Instagram prioritizes video, which it has begun promoting in its Reels feature.
column9: Most people agree that Reddit prioritizes text content, due to many subreddits being dedicated to text posts.
column10: Answers vary, but most agree that Tumblr has no priority. This may be because Tumblr supports a wide variety of content including text, image, video, and audio
column11: Overwhelmingly, people agree that TikTok solely prioritizes video, since this is the main scrolling feed.
column12: Overwhelmingly, people agree that BeReal solely prioritizes image, since this is the main scrolling feed and the only type of post users can create.
column13: Overwhelmingly, people agree that YouTube solely prioritizes video.
column14: Most people agree that Snapchat prioritizes image content, since this is the main form of content users send. However, many people believe Snapchat prioritizes video, since the content of its Discover page is entirely video
column15: There are few responses, but most people believe 4Chan prioritizes text and image content
column16: Overwhelmingly, people agree that Twitch solely prioritizes video.

column3: It is easy to create my own content.
column4: People agree that making their own content in social media is easy.
column5: Q
column6: Q
column7: Q
column8: Q, not as strong agree as Twitter or Reddit, since images are often edited before uploading
column9: Q
column10: Q
column11: Q, not as high as Twitter or Reddit since videos may need editing
column12: Q, very low barrier to entry
column13: Very varied response. While it is easy to upload a video, many videos already posted are edited and highly produced, which may be intimidating to new users.
column14: Q
column15: Q
column16: Twitch has a higher barrier to entry. People slightly agree that it is easy to create content, but very often this content needs external setup.
column17: People agree that content is easy to create, since social media is designed to encourage posting

column3: I am entertained by the content on the platform.
column4: Most people are entertained by social media! A majority of responses are between very frequent entertainment and occasional entertainment
column5: Q, a Typical social media that is entertaining
column6: People are not often entertained by LinkedIn. Although the highest number of respondents said they are occasionally entertained, responses lean negative. Content is education-based and professional, used for networking, which may make it dry
column7: Q
column8: Q
column9: Q, more very frequently . Broader content
column10: Very frequently, users of tumblr like tumblr. Possibly more user specific, self-cultivated content
column11: Q, more very frequent and frequent. Algo good recs cultivated
column12: Large range, not for entertainment
column13: Most say VF and close second F, Good recommendations, self selected
column14: Q, occasionally leaning negative. Friends are not always entertaining, and Discover content is not appealing
column15: High variance, Q, LC
column16: Very frequently, users self-select into streams to watch, self selected
column17: People follow the overall trend of being mostly entertained by social media, with most people responding that they are frequently or occasionally entertained. These are follower-based and have weaker recommendation algorithms

column3: I am educated by the content on the platform.
column4: In general, users are occasionally educated by content on their social media platforms
column5: Many users say they are occasionally educated by Facebook, but most say they are rarely or never educated. This may be due to the personal style of many posts, as well as misinformation.
column6: People are often educated by content on LinkedIn, with most respondants answering frequently or occasionally. LinkedIn is for professionals and academics, thus posts will often contain educational information about research or a new discovery.
column7: Occasionally, leaning rarely. Not a place for reliable information
column8: Rarely. A personal platform, most people post photos of themselves and their experiences, not education
column9: Frequently. Subreddits like r/TIL (Today I Learned) are focused primarily on education, with r/science one of the most popular
column10: Q
column11: Q
column12: Q
column13: Frequently, most people responding between VF and O. A lot of YouTube videos are educational, teaching abt a broad variety of topics
column14: Q
column15: Q, low confidence
column16: Most responses rarely/very rarely. A place for entertainment, not education
column17: Occasionally. Maybe stumble on some education, not focus
column18: Occasionally. Maybe stumble on some education, not focus

column3: I feel bored/unsatisfied after viewing content on the platform.
column4: Althought you'd except entertainment based platforms to rarely leave users unsatisfied, overall, users are occassionally unsatisfied.
column5: Surprisingly, Facebook is one of the platforms that struggles the most compared to other media we asked about. This could be a variety of reasons, such as not enjoying your connections posts or the recommended content, or that our respondents for facebook skewed older and that generation reflects on their view experience differently. Whatever the reason, keep this in mind!
column6:
Infrequent LinkedIn users primarily use it as a digital resume, rather 
than for its content. The platform's corporate culture inherently makes 
the content less "entertaining" than it's contemporaries, leading to 
occasional user boredom, but this is expected and some users are satisfied with that.
column7: This one a platform was one of the worst in terms of boredom. Although entertaining, maybe Q? maybe follows? maybe strucutre?
column8: Q
column9: occassionally, variety of factors (no creators? Q?)
column10: users of tumblr like tumblr
column11: Q, video content
column12: format: know what you are going to get
column13: Q, video content
column14: Snapchat's loss of creators in the 2017 redesign has hurt the quality of it's content. click through stories out of habit
column15: forum structure
column16: return to certain streamers
column17: This is one of the platforms that rarely leaves users unsatisfied.
column18: The platform's recommendation algorithm may not be as effect as its contemporaries.

column3: Misinformation is spread through the platform.
column4: Misinformation is a problem for all platforms, but it is more well known on some than others.
column5: Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal as forever marked it as suseptabile to misinfromation, especially through it's targeted ads. Posts are linked to how often they've been shared (likes, re-shared,etc.), so inflammatory misinformation is a tantalizing route to internet fame. The echo-chambers of community bubbles or recommendation bubbles can also contribute to a space where misinformation is not questioned.
column6: As a professional environment, users tend to be careful about what they post. People tend to post about their professional successes or new relevant to their field, and nothing that makes them look bad. Although misinfomation is still present on the platform, the culture limits discussion and spread.
column7: P but more
column8: Q
column9: Q
column10: Q but less / perception of less
column11: Q
column12: BeReal has limited posting features and small friend circles, so users agree that missinformation is likely not a major issue on the platform. etc.etc
column13: Q
column14: friend connections,
column15: Anonymity, culture
column16: Although responses were divided, generally misinformation is occassionally or rarely spread. Streamers will generally control the discussion, so the stop of misinformation relies on them etc etc
column17: Posts are linked to how often they've been shared (like, re-shared,etc.) so inflammatory misinformation is a tantalizing route to internet fame. The echo-chambers of community bubbles or recommendation bubbles can also contribute to a space where misinformation is not questioned.

column3: Agency
I can control what I see on the platform.
column4: Social media will always be tied to the content a user cultivates, whether thats from following creators or from trying to tune their recommendation algorithm. This isn't always a process that the user will always have minute control of, but the user will play at least a minimal roll.
column5: The recommendation algorithm can feel out of a user's control. Although friendships are valuable on the platform, the lean towards newsfeed and other recommendation algorithms may make the user feel powerless at times.
column6: Survey respondents may only user profile features, so the survey responses may not accurately reflect the feed. Overall, posts will be recommended if posted or liked by a connection, so your feed will be linked to your friend's choices.
column7: Twitter's recommendation algortihm interjects with content you chose to follow, so some of the content will not be user choice
column8: recommendations spliced into followed content
column9: With less emphasis on a recommendation features, users chose which communities they want to view content from
column10: Users can chose whether or not to enable the recommendation algorithm, so it is possible to only view content from bloggers you chose to follow. Word and tag blocking further let you limit content you do not want to see.
column11: Recomendation only
column12: The friends you chose to add will be the only content you see
column13: Since YouTube content is videos, it is a choice to watch an consume content. Tiktok has a little less control, as it is based on watch video perscribed for you, while YouTube gives a menu of options which users chose from.
column14: Answers vary wildly here, but, most users will be interacting with friends or viewing stories of their close connections. Some of the tabloid content cannot be avoided
column15: Users tend to troll other forums
column16: The long-form nature of Twitch content main users will chose to watch a streamer for a while, and then switch to another. Instead of the scrolling and searching nature of social media, Twitch users tend to chose content for themselves.

column3: I can control the quantity and types of advertisements I see.
column4: Most social media platforms use ads as a primary revenue source.
column5: Facebook makes $114 Billion dollars annually off of it's ad spots. Although there are some tools for hiding certain ads and understanding what demographics users are targetted as, they may not be widely known or understood by users.
column6: LinkedIn makes $3B dollars annunally off of it's ad spots. There are settings to disable personlized ads and a premium model, which may be why our participants y lean towards slightly disagree over strongly disagree, but this may just as well be because our survey respondents may primarily use profile features, when ads show up in the feed.

column12: No ads!

column15: Same number of No Ads to Strong Disagrees. Web only + adblockers. There are no settings to change ads

column3: The platform recommends me content that aligns with my previous interests.
column4: Social media wants to entertain you, so, overall, all platforms will tend to show you things you are interested in.
column5: Although Facebook's recommendation algortihm will recommend you your interests, it is not as good at it as it's video counterparts. Your connections posts will show up frequently, which may or may not relate to your hobbies.
column6: LinkedIn is not known for a strong recommendation algorithm. The feed will mostly be comprised of posts your connections have likes or companies you have followed, not recommended content. The professional attitude means much of the content will not align with hobbies, but may align with your professional interests.
column7: Although Twitter recommendation algortihm will recommend you your interests, it is not as strong at it as it's video counterparts.
column8: Although Instagram's recommendation algortihm will recommend you your interests, it is not as strong at it as it's video counterparts.
column9: Although Reddit's recommendation or "hotness" algortihm will recommend you your interests, it is not as strong at it as it's video counterparts.
column10: Tumblr's content depends on what you follow; tags and blogs. Although tumblr is experimenting wiht recommendation algorithmns, the general user base hasn't warmed up to it yet and instead rely on their own content filtering.
column11: Along with Youtube, Tik Tok's watch-time based video recommendation algorithm is good at finding videos that align with user interests. As long as you watch videos you are interested in, the algorithmn will get better at showing you videos you are interested in. With lower barrier to entry due to shorter videos and trends, there is more content for the algorithmn to recommend even faster.
column12: BeReal does not have a recommendation alorithmn. It is exclusivly your friend's posts from within the last 24 hours.
column13: Along with Tiktok, Youtube's watch-time based video recommendation algorithm is good at finding videos that align with user interests. As long as you watch videos you are interested in, the algorithmn will get better at showing you videos you are interested in.
column14: Snapchat's tabloid content and lack of creators makes it weaker than other social media for recommendations. It is much stronger as a messenger app.
column15: 4Chan is known for shocking content and completely lack a recommendation algorithmn, so users do not often go there to find stuff they know they will like..
column16: There is high variance in these answers. Twitch tends to recommend channels based on view count or content types you have previously watched (for example. if you watch a streamer play a video game, you may be recommended other streamers playing this game). In general, Twitch is creator driven, so you may be recommended a creator you end up liking even if you don't like the games they olay.

column3: I find content on the platform that I wish I had not seen.
column4: Sometimes the internet will show you content that feels like a waste of time or is actively painful or annoying to think about. In general, this will happen ocassioanlly accross all platforms, but some have more shock prone cultures than others.
column5: The recommendation algorithmn is not very strong, but can still recommend content that feels like a waste of time or makes your day a little worse. If you can stick to content from trusted loved ones, you may avoid some of this content, but Facebook was one of the lower performing platforms on this question.
column6: Once again, the culture of professionalism keeps shocking content to a minimum.
column7: Completely rec algo based, and sometimes the algorith will miss
column8: rec algo good and bad
column9: sometimes shocking content, tied 2nd to last with twitter and fb
column10: Surprising and strange content may still pop up on your dash, but high moderation tools let users control what they do not want to see.
column12: BeReal's special content design means that the posts you will see are just your friends, so, unless a friend posts something in their one post for the day, you will likely be safe from shocking content
column13: In general, Youtube prefers to recommend monetized videos, and those tend to follow community guidelines. Although rabbit holes and surprising videos can leave you feeling shocked, Youtube trys to be very business friendly.
column14: Answers vary wildly here, but, most users will be interacting with friends or viewing stories of their close connections. Some of the tabloid content can be shocking, but sticking with content posted by connection will keep you safe.
column15: Low moderation, shocking boards
column16: Strong community led content moderation

column3: The platform fosters a safe environment for all users.
column4: Although many social media strive to encourage a safe environment for all, success varies widly. User culture tends to determine how safe a platform feels, but some recommendation algortihms can lead to dangerous rabbitholes with harmful rhetoric.
column5: Facebook has struggled with its contents moderation. Reportadly, Facebook used to prioritized posts with "angry" reactions in the news feed, which was critized for likely spreading more controversial content that could lead to more controversy within user spaces. Facebook struggles with scammers and data harvesting with third party apps, which can lead to, in the worst cases, identity theft.
column6: LinkedIn lets you privatize almost everything on your profile, with granualar preference based on degrees of connection to a person. The business focused culture keep interactions clean and professional, so issues like bullying and hate speach are often mitigated by the culture.
column7: Debate culture, but can have good circles
column8: mostly friends so most users will have a safe experience, but discussion of body image issues
column9: known for debate culture, with some niche content that can create unsafe spaced.
column10: Early Tumblr culture revolved around intensely feminist ideas, which encourage reflection on issues that disadvantaged people face, such members of the LGBT community, people of color, or disabled people. This culture historically was, at times, more argumentative that accepting, but the ideals of their ideologies guide the community to be more understanding than others communities are. Furthermore, Tumblr provides tools to block words or tags to help users moderate their own content. The general culture also encourages blocking other blogs for any reason at all to curate your own experience, further empowering users to create pleasant online spaces for themselves.
column11: algorithmic bubbles
column12: High privacy, based on friendship, culture based on your friends culture.
column13: less discussion, more creator led, but algortihmn can push dangerous rhetoric. Many users wont see any unsafe content, but some may and some creators may be bullied
column14: The disappearing pictures can make sharing risque content tempting but data hacks make it dangerous. Snap maps, if left unattened, let any connection know your location, which can be abused. Some believe that the Snapchat filters have led to body dismorphia in teens.
column15: Known for shocking content
column16: high moderation tools, mod teams. recently banned gambling.

column3: I revisit content on the platform.
column4: Users tend to revist content on social media, as they might want to review content they found entertaining, but it varies greatly. This questions hoped to illuminate the searchablity of certain websites, as you cannot revisit content if you cannot find it, as well as the value of revisiting content on certain sites.
column5: Many users revisit content from Facebook, whether to share funny videos with friends or to look back on photos with loved ones. The "saved" and "memories" pages let you look back on content you've made or marked.
column6: LinkedIn content is business focused, so it won't be revisited for entertainment purposes as often as other media. There are features for saving posts and jobs, but those rely on user action, and it;s search features aid primarily in finding pages and current chatter, not revisiting a post. Our users may primarily use profile features, so this data may be skewed.
column7: High variablity, but when tweets are so short, they are hard to search, rely on likes and saves
column8: High variablity, but post search options are limited unless tags are extensively used and, even then, those posts may get drowned out. rely on likes and saves
column9: Reddit's search features, which can filter by subreddit and search in comments, allows for easy access etcetc, though some do not
column10: One of the highest for revisting among our participants. Tagging, infimous posts returning to the dash, drafts
column11: Unique video content and culture, with catching facts + story times, want to revisit with friends / earworms. videos lack "titles" to search features are not as strong as contemporaries, so may be unable to revisit
column12: Dissappearing
column13: This is overwheleming the top social media website for revisiting content. YouTube's search is advanced, relying on video popularity, titles, tags, and more. searchable history, watch later, playlist saving
column14: Disappearing, consistent content is "tabloid" content
column15: High variability, but the low search features impare re-visitability.
column16: High variability, but some may put on their favorite vods from streamers they like while others may only enjoy the live experience
